page.title: 13History of Winster
page.content: In 1066 Winster know as Winsterine meaning thorn bushes covered 12 acres of taxable land and a substantial wood. Present Church on site of Norman Chapel. Elizabeth 1 in 1596 restored grant of lead mining trade. Late 17th century, population 600 at which time a village now abandoned existed, west of Miners Standard Inn, called Islington. Winster lead industry boomed. Population rose to 2000 around 1720 - 1770. Most of present village built in this period. Population fell with drop in lead prices and substantial flooding of mines and has remained at figure of 780 since 1801. Winster was a market town and also held fairs. These ceased around 1870. Wakes Week is held in late June.
